awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving the stability, usability, and speed of the RevBayes platform for phylogenetic analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
All species are related to one another through an unknown genealogical tree: the `Tree of Life.' Genealogical trees for small parts of the Tree of Life are called `phylogenies' by biologists; there is more interest in phylogenies today than at any time in the past. Phylogenies are crucial in fields such as epidemiology where they are used to track the spread of infectious disease and molecular biology where they are used to understand how molecular pathways developed. The `Tree of Life' can be discovered by comparing the characteristics of different organisms. Traditionally, phylogenies were reconstructed by comparing anatomical traits across different species. More recently, DNA sequence information from individual genes, or even full genomes, are compared to estimate phylogenies. This project will continue the development of the RevBayes computer program that biologists use to reconstruct phylogenies. The program takes as input the comparative information from the organisms of interest. The output of the program is the probabilities of the best phylogenies that explain the comparative data. Specifically, the project will improve the speed, usability, and reliability of the program.

RevBayes is the successor of the MrBayes program which is widely used by biologists to estimate phylogeny. However, the RevBayes program represents a significant departure from MrBayes. The RevBayes program implements an R-like language to describe statistical models. The model is represented in computer memory as a graph in which the vertices of the graph are the parameters and the edges represent the dependencies between parameters. RevBayes uses Markov chain Monte Carlo to approximate the posterior probability distribution of parameters. This project will improve the RevBayes program in several signficant ways: (1) unit and integration testing will be implemented to improve the reliability of the program; (2) computational resources, such as multiple cores or GPUs, will be taken better advantage of, to improve the speed of the program; (3) a cross-platform graphical user interface will be developed to improve the usability of the program; (4) output will be bundled to improve the reproducibility of the program; and (5) the program will be made to work with other software programs, to improve its interoperability. Finally, several workshops will be hosted by the participants in which phylogenetic theory will be described with emphasis of application of the theory to real-world problems using RevBayes. The source code can be found on the Github site at http://revbayes.github.io/about.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
Statistical phylogenetic methods are critical to basic and applied research seeking to elucidate and mitigate the impacts of important societal problems, such as climate change, vanishing biodiversity, and global pandemics. These methods use complex statistical models of evolutionary processes to understand historical and future evolutionary patterns. Software implementing statistical phylogenetic approaches is used to infer relationships among evolutionary lineages and their ages, ancestral states of evolving traits, the tempo of evolutionary change, and much more. Phylogenetic studies provide insight into how organisms adapt (or go extinct) in response to changing environments, catalog biodiversity, and uncover the dynamics of infectious diseases. Beyond these applications, statistical phylogenetic methods are essential for a wide range of research questions, including those that concern gene family evolution, species tree relationships, the history of human culture, cancer and tumor progression, and the mechanics of the immune system. 

 

The collaboratively developed, open-source software project RevBayes (revbayes.com) provides a flexible platform for statistical phylogenetic analysis under complex and biologically meaningful models. The complexity available in RevBayes comes from a design using probabilistic graphical models and an interpreted programming language called Rev. The core RevBayes modeling package, accessory tools, documentation, and user training materials are developed and maintained by an international team of contributors. 

 

This Development award supported several activities that will enable the long-term stability of the project and the user-developer community. The target of our efforts involved: (1) technical advances to the code and infrastructure; (2) implementing and testing analysis methods and algorithms; (3) better documentation and developer communication; and (4) improving the user experience through intuitive interfaces, simplified installation, thorough documentation and training materials, and interactive workshops. 


Intellectual Merit


The RevBayes team grew to over 50 contributors to the project and associated components. Members of this collaborative community represent more than 20 institutions. The RevBayes core modeling package now contains over 300,000 lines of code in over 2,900 files and tagged releases have been downloaded over 14,000 times. This growth was facilitated by our work to improve the code quality, infrastructure, and development workflow practices. To achieve this we upgraded the C++ standard for the core package and overhauled our GitHub repositories. We implemented new code-contribution practices that ensure better communication, avoid replication, and prevent the release of damaged code. Several new methods have become available in RevBayes since these changes, e.g., macroevolutionary analysis under models that account for fossil data, cophylogenetic methods, and polymorphism-aware species-tree estimation. We additionally applied RevBayes to empirical datasets to understand the evolutionary histories of penguins and rove beetles; and showed using simulations that statistical phylogenetic methods can refine age estimates of poorly dated fossil formations. 


The advances to methods and the RevBayes project are now maintained by automated integration tests via GitHub Actions. We greatly expanded the test suite to cover a wide range of possible analyses. Additionally, because the development workflow requires pull requests to pass all tests and community review before new code is merged into the stable branch, users can be confident that released versions are reliable. 


During the award period, we also worked to enhance the user experience thorough several efforts that included: (1) overhauling the RevBayes website, (2) creating a Rev language reference, (3) developing intuitive interfaces and accessory tools, (4) providing more accessible tutorials, and (5) offering training in workshops. In particular, the RevScripter interface provides a menu-driven graphical-user interface for setting up standard phylogenetic analyses and helps new users learn how models translate into Rev scripts. 


Broader Impacts


The workshops supported by this award were held virtually in 2020 and 2021 because of the COVID-19 pandemic. We used this opportunity to reevaluate how we offer workshops and consider ways to make them more accessible. We developed a “flipped workshop” that involved a mix of synchronous and asynchronous learning. This allowed participants to work through the materials at their own pace while also having access to several expert instructors. The virtual and flipped workshop format made it possible to include participants and instructors from 24 different countries. Many participants had never had the opportunity to attend a phylogenetics workshop previously because of cost or challenges with obtaining visas. The materials we created for the virtual workshops are all openly available. These include several video guides hosted on YouTube. It is clear this format enhances the accessibility to new methods, and our experiences offering virtual workshops led us to publish a paper describing the format and the lessons we learned. 


At Iowa State University, this award trained two postdoctoral researchers, three PhD students, and one undergraduate student. The undergraduate student was the lead developer of RevScripter and presented posters on this work at the 2019 and 2020 National Diversity in STEM Conference organized by the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics & Native Americans in Science. 



 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2023
Modified by: Tracy A Heath

    The RevBayes Workflow
  • This course covered 8 core topics, each with a detailed tutorial and video guide. The course aimed to provide enough time for participants to complete the tutorials while considering how the methods will be applicable to their own data and research (see: https://doi.org/10.18061/bssb.v1i2.8425).
    Jo�lle Braido-Sottani et al. 2022. https://doi.org/10.18061/bssb.v1i2.8425
    Creative Commons

    The topics covered by the "Stay-at-Home" RevBayes virtual workshop
  • Instructors (yellow), 2020 participants (blue), and 2021 participants (red) attended workshops via Zoom. The black line delineates the boundary between UTC+3 and UTC+4 time zones, which determined the selection of participants in the two workshops. Workshop logos were inspired by current events.
    Barido-Sottani et. al. https://doi.org/10.18061/bssb.v1i2.8425
